"Midsize" is more specific than both because it specifies the classification within a category, while "mid-size" could apply to any size near the middle range.
Next, we look at the less specific adjective. In sentence (A), "midsize" is more specific than "rubber gray". In sentence (B), "mid-size" is less specific than both "midsize" and "rubber gray".
Following those rules, sentence (A) should be (A) because "midsize" appears first.
The correct adjective order in sentence (B) is (B). Although the less specific adjective comes later and there is a pair of opposing words ("midsize" vs. "rubber"), "mid-size" is a sound word that doesn't include the opposing meaning, unlike "midsize", which refers to a size midway between two measurements.

After analyzing these characteristics, we can see that the order gives us the most information in a concise manner without needing to repeat adjectives unnecessarily.
